case_name: Hazrat Syed Mastershid Ali Al Quadari v. Syed Shah Rasheed Ali Al Quadari

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 237 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 237 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated December 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 13, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 117 of 1954.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court appeal from Original Order No. 117 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 117 of 1954. BSen, P. K. Chatterjee and S. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on February 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This appeal is as much without substance, as it was unnecessary.

facts.text: Appellant Hazrat Syed Mastershid Ali Al Quadari is eldest son of Hazrat Sahib Syed Shah Mastershid Ali Al Quadari.

anchor.surface_text: Hazrat Syed Mastershid Ali Al Quadari  the appellant  is the eldest son of one Hazrat Sahib Syed Shah Mastershid Ali Al Quadari  shortly, Hazrat Sahib , the first Mutawalli

facts.text: Hazrat Sahib was first Mutawalli of wakf created on August 9, 1931 for maintenance of Muslim Pir shrine in Midnapur.

anchor.surface_text: , the first Mutawalli of a wakf created on August 9, 1931, for the maintenance of the shrine of a Muslim Pir in the town of Midnapur. After the death of Hazrat Sahib,

facts.text: After death of Hazrat Sahib, appellant claimed to succeed as Sajjadanashin as eldest son.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hazrat Sahib, the appellant, claiming to succeed to his father as Sajjadanashin, being his eldest son, made an application To the Commissioner

facts.text: Appellant made application to Commissioner under Bengal Wakf Act.

anchor.surface_text: being his eldest son, made an application To the Commissioner under the Bengal Wakf Act. His younger brother, Syed Shah Rushaid Ali Al Quadari, opposed his claim,

facts.text: Younger brother Syed Shah Rushaid Ali Al Quadari opposed appellant's claim on ground of nomination by Hazrat Sahib.

anchor.surface_text: His younger brother, Syed Shah Rushaid Ali Al Quadari, opposed his claim, the ground being that he was numberinated as the succes- sor by Hazrat Sahib. While this companytroversy

facts.text: Commissioner appointed Syed Shah Rasheed Ali Al Quadari, third son of Hazrat Sahib, as temporary Mutawalli under s.40 of Bengal Wakf Act.

anchor.surface_text: While this companytroversy was afoot, the Commissioner, acting under s. 40 of the Bengal Wakf Act, appointed Syed Shah Rasheed Ali Al Quadari  the third son of Hazrat Sahib  as a temporary Mutawalli.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition in Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 against Commissioner's appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved a petition in the Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution against the appointment, which was allowed by Sinha, J. and the order of the Commissioner was set aside.

facts.text: Sinha J. allowed petition and set aside Commissioner's order.

anchor.surface_text: which was allowed by Sinha, J. and the order of the Commissioner was set aside. On appeal to the Divisional Bench, companysisting of Chakravarti, C. J. and Lahiri, J.

facts.text: Divisional Bench of Calcutta High Court consisting of Chakravarti C.J. and Lahiri J. reversed Sinha J. and dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Divisional Bench, companysisting of Chakravarti, C. J. and Lahiri, J.  as he then was , the order of Sinha, J. was reversed, and the petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed with special leave. It is companytended in this appeal that the order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal,

facts.text: Appellant contended Commissioner's appointment illegal as only Board could appoint under Government Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended in this appeal that the order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal, because under the Rules framed by the Government, only the Board companystituted under the Bengal Wakf Act companyld make the appointment.

facts.text: Bengal Wakf Act s.40 allows Board to appoint temporary Mutawalli if no Mutawalli or impediment to appointment.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with sections 40 and 29 of the Bengal Wakf Act. Section 40 reads as follows In the case of any Wakf of which there is numberMutwalli or where there appears to the Board to be an impediment to the appointment of amutwalli the Board,

facts.text: Bengal Wakf Act s.29 allows Board to authorize Commissioner to exercise Board's powers and duties.

anchor.surface_text: subject to any order of a companypetent Court, may appoint for such period as it thinks fit a person to act as Mutwalli. Section 29 provides The Board may, from time to time, authorize the Commissioner

facts.text: Board adopted resolution on April 24, 1936 authorizing Commissioner to exercise powers under s.40.

anchor.surface_text: On April 24, 1936, the Board adopted the following resolution  2 . In exercise of the powers vested in them under Section 29 of the Act this Board resolve that the Commissioner of Wakfs be authorised to exercise and perform,

facts.text: Government Rules require Commissioner to report to Board on disputes over Mutawalli vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: These Rules are If it appears to the Commissioner that there is numbermutwalli, in the case of any wakf, or that a a vacancy in the office of the mutwalli has been caused by death, resignation, retirement or removal of th former mutwalli,

facts.text: Board may appoint Mutawalli under s.40 on receipt of Commissioner's report.

anchor.surface_text: and a dispute has arisen between two or more rival claimants to the vacancy, and such dispute is likely to affect the interests of the Wakf, he may institute an enquiry and report the result thereof to the Board with his recommendation. 2On receipt of the report

facts.text: Appellant contended no impediment to permanent Mutawalli appointment, only challenge to his candidacy.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen, however, companytends that the appointment of a temporary Mutawalli companyld only be made if there was an impediment to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, and that there was numberimpediment to such an appointment but a challenge to the appellant as a candidate.

facts.text: Court found dispute constituted impediment to appointment of permanent Mutawalli.

anchor.surface_text: The word impediment means hindrance or obstruction, and there was certainly an obstruction to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, while the dispute remained undecided. This point has numberforce whatever.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appeal has numberforce whatever. The appellant chose the extraordinary companyrse of dragging the respondents twice to the High Court and again to this Court merely to challenge an order of temporary duration,

facts.text: Main controversy over succession remained undecided.

anchor.surface_text: while the main companytroversy remained outstanding for years and companyld have been decided by number. The appeal fails, and is dismissed.

facts.text: Commissioner acted under delegation from Board and was competent to appoint temporary Mutawalli.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules cannot affect the power of the Board to delegate its functions under s. 29, and harmonious companystruction requires that the Rules should give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus companypetent to make the appointment.

issues.text: whether the order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal, because under the Rules framed by the Government, only the Board constituted under the Bengal Wakf Act could make the appointment

anchor.surface_text: It is contended in this appeal that the order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal, because under the Rules framed by the Government, only the Board constituted under the Bengal Wakf Act could make the appointment.

issues.text: whether the Commissioner can only make a report to the Board, and the Board alone can make the appointment under s. 40

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that the Commissioner can only make a report to the Board, and the Board alone can make the appointment, and refers to two Rules framed by Government.

issues.text: whether the appointment of a temporary Mutawalli could only be made if there was an impediment to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, and that there was no impediment but only a challenge to the appellant as a candidate

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen, however, contends that the appointment of a temporary Mutawalli could only be made if there was an impediment to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, and that there was no impediment to such an appointment but a challenge to the appellant as a candidate.

issues.text: whether the delegation was only of powers or also of duties of the Board

anchor.surface_text: The question which seemed to have largely engaged attention in the High Court, namely, whether the delegation was only of powers or also of duties of the Board, was not argued before us, though it formed the subject of considerable discussion in the statements of the case.

arguments.claim: The order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal because under the Rules framed by the Government only the Board constituted under the Bengal Wakf Act could make the appointment

anchor.surface_text: It is contended in this appeal that the order of the Commissioner appointing a temporary Mutawalli was illegal, because under the Rules framed by the Government, only the Board constituted under the Bengal Wakf Act could make the appointment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Bengal Wakf Act companyld make the appointment. This argument, in our opinion, is wholly unsound. The learned Chief Justice of the High Court examined

arguments.court_reasoning: Board authorised Commissioner under s.29 via 1936 resolution to exercise s.40 powers; Rules subordinate and cease to apply post-delegation under harmonious construction

arguments.claim: The Commissioner can only make a report to the Board and the Board alone can make the appointment under the two Government Rules

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that the Commissioner can only make a report to the Board, and the Board alone can make the appointment, and refers to two Rules framed by Government. These Rules are If it appears to the Commissioner that there is no mutwalli...

arguments.court_reasoning: True where no delegation but once Board delegates under s.29 via resolution Commissioner acts for Board and Rules cease to apply; harmonious construction prioritises statutory delegation over rules

arguments.claim: Appointment of temporary Mutawalli could only be made if impediment to permanent Mutawalli and there was no impediment but only challenge to appellant as candidate

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen, however, contends that the appointment of a temporary Mutawalli could only be made if there was an impediment to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, and that there was no impediment to such an appointment but a challenge to the appellant as a candidate.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Impediment means hindrance or obstruction and dispute created obstruction to permanent appointment while undecided

arguments.claim: Board may under s.29 authorise Commissioner to exercise powers and duties under Act including s.40 appointment of temporary Mutawalli

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with sections 40 and 29 of the Bengal Wakf Act. Section 40 reads as follows... Section 29 provides The Board may, from time to time, authorize the Commissioner to exercise and perform... On April 24, 1936, the Board adopted the following resolution... powers of this Board under section 40...

arguments.claim: Government Rules give way to statutory delegation under s.29 and harmonious construction requires Rules subordinate when delegation made

anchor.surface_text: The Rules cannot affect the power of the Board to delegate its functions under s. 29, and harmonious construction requires that the Rules should give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus competent to make the appointment.

arguments.claim: Dispute between claimants constitutes impediment to appointment of permanent Mutawalli under s.40 as impediment means hindrance or obstruction

anchor.surface_text: The word impediment means hindrance or obstruction, and there was certainly an obstruction to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, while the dispute remained undecided. This point has no force whatever.

arguments.claim: Delegation of powers carries duties where powers and duties interconnected and inseparable

anchor.surface_text: The question which seemed to have largely engaged attention in the High Court, namely, whether the delegation was only of powers or also of duties of the Board... Where powers and duties are interconnected and it is not possible to separate one from the other... the delegation of powers takes with it the duties... reference may be made to Mungoni v. Attorney-General of Northern Rhodesia.

arguments.claim: Appeal lacks substance as it unnecessarily challenged temporary order while main succession controversy undecided causing delay

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appeal has no force whatever. The appellant chose the extraordinary course of dragging the respondents twice to the High Court and again to this Court merely to challenge an order of temporary duration, while the main controversy remained outstanding for years...

holdings.text: The Rules cannot affect the power of the Board to delegate its functions under s. 29, and harmonious construction requires that the Rules should give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus competent to make the appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules cannot affect the power of the Board to delegate its functions under s. 29, and harmonious construction requires that the Rules should give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus companypetent to make the appointment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power under s.29 allows Board to delegate to Commissioner; subordinate Government Rules inapplicable post-delegation under harmonious construction principles.

holdings.text: The word impediment means hindrance or obstruction, and there was certainly an obstruction to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, while the dispute remained undecided. This point has no force whatever.

anchor.surface_text: The word impediment means hindrance or obstruction, and there was certainly an obstruction to the appointment of a permanent Mutawalli, while the dispute remained undecided. This point has numberforce whatever.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ongoing dispute between rival claimants to Mutawalli position constitutes an impediment under s.40 as it hinders permanent appointment until resolved.

holdings.text: Where powers and duties are interconnected and it is not possible to separate one from the other in such wise that powers may be delegated while duties are retained and vice versa, the delegation of powers takes with it the duties.

anchor.surface_text: Where powers and duties are interconnected and it is not possible to separate one from the other in such wise that powers may be delegated while duties are retained and vice versa, the delegation of powers takes with it the duties. The proposition hardly needs authority but if one were necessary, reference may be made to Mungoni v. Attomey- General of Northern Rhodesia

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delegation under s.29 transfers both powers and inseparable duties; principle supported by foreign precedent though issue not argued before Supreme Court.

holdings.text: These two provisions of the Act show only too plainly that a temporary Mutawalli can be appointed either by the Board, or, if the powers and duties be delegated to the Commissioner, by the Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: These two provisions of the Act show only too plainly that a temporary Mutawalli can be appointed either by the Board, or, if the powers and duties be delegated to the Commissioner, by the Commissioner. The appellant companytends that the Commissioner can only make a report to the Board,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.29 expressly authorizes Board to delegate s.40 powers to Commissioner, as implemented by 1936 resolution.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the appeal has no force whatever. The appeal fails, and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appeal has numberforce whatever. The appellant chose the extraordinary companyrse of dragging the respondents twice to the High Court and again to this Court merely to challenge an order of temporary duration,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's challenge to temporary appointment lacks merit as Commissioner competent and impediment existed; unnecessary litigation delayed main wakf dispute resolution.

precedents.cited_proposition: Where powers and duties are interconnected and it is not possible to separate one from the other in such wise that powers may be delegated while duties are retained and vice versa, the delegation of powers takes with it the duties.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails, and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal against the High Court's dismissal of the petition challenging the Commissioner's appointment of a temporary Mutawalli is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules cannot affect the power of the Board to delegate its functions under s. 29, and harmonious construction requires that the Rules should give way, when there is a delegation of the powers of the Board. The Commissioner was thus companypetent to make the appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Where powers and duties are interconnected and it is not possible to separate one from the other in such wise that powers may be delegated while duties are retained and vice versa, the delegation of powers takes with it the duties. The proposition hardly needs authority but if one were necessary, reference may be made to Mungoni v. Attomey- General of Northern Rhodesia
